Fig. 1 XRD patterns of Ce-Ti-Zr samples. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Raman spectra of Ce-Ti-Zr samples. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XPS spectra of O 1 s (A), Ti 2p (B), Zr 3d (C), Ce 3d (D) for Ce-Ti-Zr samples. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 H2-TPR (A) and O2-TPD (B and C) profiles of Ce-Ti-Zr samples. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 NH3-TPD profiles (A) and Py-FT-IR spectra (B) of Ce-Ti-Zr samples. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 CH2Cl2 conversion curves on Ce-Ti-Zr (A) and Ce-Ti (B) catalysts, and T50 and T90 vs Ce/Ce+Ti+Zr ratios (C); gas composition: 1000 ppm CH2Cl2/air; GHSV = 30,000 mL g−1 h−1; catalyst amount: 100 mg. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 The rate at 250 °C vs Ce/Ce+Ti+Zr (A) and surface oxygen density (B) for CH2Cl2 oxidation; gas composition: 1000 ppm CH2Cl2/air; GHSV = 30,000 mL g−1 h−1; catalyst amount: 100 mg. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The effect of oxygen concentration on CH2Cl2 oxidation over Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 at 310 °C; gas composition: 1000 ppm CH2Cl2, 0.1–20% O2 and N2 balance; GHSV = 30,000 mL g−1 h−1; catalyst amount: 100 mg. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The selectivity for Cl2 (A), CH3Cl, CO and CO2 (B) during CH2Cl2 oxidation over Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts; gas composition: 1000 ppm CH2Cl2/air; GHSV = 30,000 mL g−1 h−1; catalyst amount: 100 mg. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The stability of Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts on feed stream at 310 °C; gas composition: 1000 ppm CH2Cl2/air; GHSV = 30,000 mL g−1 h−1; catalyst amount: 100 mg. CH2Cl2 catalytic oxidation over Ce-Ti-Zr mixed oxide catalysts Wei Sun Conceptualization Validation Formal analysis Investigation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Visualization a Shijie Shao Validation Data curation Software a Jun Pan Resources b Yangyang Wang Resources b Hangqi Xia Investigation a Xiaohui Gao Methodology a Hao Zhang Validation a Qiguang Dai Methodology Supervision a Li Wang Methodology Data curation Supervision a ⁎ Xingyi Wang Conceptualization Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, PR China Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 PR China Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis, School of Chemistry and molecular Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, PR China b Aviation Electromechanical System Integration of Aviation Science and Technology Key Laboratory, Nanjing 211106, PR China Aviation Electromechanical System Integration of Aviation Science and Technology Key Laboratory Nanjing 211106 PR China Aviation Electromechanical System Integration of Aviation Science and Technology Key Laboratory, Nanjing 211106, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Ce-Ti-Zr mixed oxide catalysts prepared by sol-gel method were used in catalytic combustion of CH2Cl2. The characterization reveals that the incorporation of Ce and Zr into TiO2 anatase or Ti and Zr into CeO2 fluorite promotes hydroxyl groups, Lewis acidity and surface oxygen through the formation of Ti-O-Zr, Ti-O-Ce and Ce-O-Zr species. Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts show high activity for CH2Cl2 oxidation with the rate of 5.66 × 10−3–6.45 × 10−3 μmol s−1 m−2 at 250 °C and high stability for 50 h. The substitution of surface oxygen for Cl maintains the availability of Ti-OH and thus promotes Cl removal as HCl, which is verified by a great increase in the stable activity of physically closely contacted mixture of separated CeO2 and TiO2 or Ti9Zr1 particles. In situ FT-IR shows that CH2Cl2 interacts with Ti-OH to form -O-CH2-O-, which is quickly rearranged into formate. Finally, formate is oxidized with surface oxygen into CO or CO2. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Catalytic combustion Dichloromethane Titanium Zirconium Cerium 1 Introduction Chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs), such as chlorobenzene (CB) and dichloromethane (CH2Cl2) which originate from waste incineration, chlorine bleaching and other industrial processes [1,2], are extremely hazardous contaminants due to their potential toxicity as carcinogens and teratogens, bioaccumulation in animals and long-term persistence in the environment. As a result, stringent environmental regulations have been imposed on the emissions containing such compounds in many countries [3]. Generally, the catalytic combustion is thought to be one of the most promising technology for the removal of CVOCs in waste gases, due to its high effectiveness (between 250 and 550 °C) and low consumption of energy (without additional fuel) when compared to a thermal process [3,4]. Noble metal catalysts were highly active for CVOC's catalytic combustion. However, they were susceptible to the adsorption of chlorine formed during CVOC's decomposition, and thus showed high selectivity for chlorination [5,6]. Suitable Brønsted acidity and pore structure of molecular sieve catalysts could promote the adsorption and activation of CVOCs, but the deposition of coke on Brønsted acid led inevitably to the deactivation of these catalysts [7]. The transition metal oxides, such as Co [8], Mn [9], Cr [10], Fe [11] and V [12], were resistant to chlorine poisoning, and thus used often for CVOC's catalytic combustion. Our previous work showed that the Ce-based catalysts showed high activity for the oxidation of chlorinated aromatic compounds, due to their unique redox and high ability for C-Cl dissociation [13–15]. However, Cl adsorbed strongly on the surface could be removed as Cl2 only at high temperature, where Deacon reaction (HCl + O2 → Cl2 + H2O) occurred. Additionally, in the oxidation of chlorinated alkane, such as CH2Cl2 and CH2Cl-CH2Cl, Ru/Al2O3 catalysts modified with Ce presented high stable activity, because inorganic Cl species could be effectively removed as Cl2 [16]. While a considerable volatility of Ru species at high temperature could limit the industrial application of Ru in catalytic combustion. As known, the chlorinated alkane could be activated on hydroxyl group to form reactive alkoxy at low temperature [17,18]. Stable and nontoxic TiO2 possessed abundant hydroxyl groups on the surface, which often were used for anchoring the catalytically active components and adsorbing the reactants, as seen in the cases of Cr/TiO2 [19], V/TiO2 [20] and Mn/TiO2 [21]. The solid solution structure of Ti and other metal oxides, such as Ti-O-Sn [22], Ti-O-Fe [23] and Ti-O-Zr [24], was favorable for the formation of Lewis acid, on which Cl atom could be abstracted from C-Cl of chlorinated alkane [17]. However, Ti-based catalysts deactivated quickly, due to the interaction between Ti and Cl to form Ti-Cl [18]. DFT calculation indicated that inorganic Cl species formed in CVOC's decomposition preferred to adsorb on oxygen vacancy [25] or substituted for surface or lattice oxygen [12]. While the competition of surface oxygen with Cl for oxygen vacancy could be dependent on either Cl-metal bond energy or surface oxygen [13]. As reported previously, the strength of Ti-O bond was higher than that of Ti-Cl bond [26]. Here, there is probably an opportunity for designing effective catalysts that were composed of Ce, Ti and other transitional metal oxides for CVOC's catalytic oxidation. In this work, Ce-Ti-Zr mixed oxide catalysts were prepared by sol-gel method and investigated in terms of the effect of hydroxyl group, surface oxygen and Lewis acid on the activity, selectivity and stability in CH2Cl2 catalytic oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ti9Zr1 oxide catalyst was prepared with sol-gel method. 1.3 g Zr(NO3)4·5H2O (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., 99.5%) was dissolved in a solution that was composed of 4.6 g deionized water and 20 mL ethanol. The formed solution was added into 20 mL ethanol solution containing 7.8 g Ti[OCH(CH3)2]4 (Adamas Reagent Co., Ltd., 98%) under stirring. After transformed into gel, the solution was dried at 110 °C for 12 h and then heated to 500 °C at 2 °C min−1. Finally, the solid obtained was thermally treated with calcinations in air at 500 °C for 4 h. For the Ce-Ti-Zr mixed oxide catalysts, a given content of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd., 99.95%) was added into Zr(NO3)4 ethanol aqueous solution. The formed solution was added into ethanol solution containing Ti[OCH(CH3)2]4. H2O/Ti (mol), Ti/Zr (atom) and Ce/Ce+Ti+Zr (atom) was 10, 9 and 0.1–0.5, respectively (total amount of metal ions was 0.04 mol), and the volume of ethanol was 40 mL. Thermal treatment was carried out by the above mentioned procedure. The obtained catalysts were denoted as Cex(Ti9Zr1)y, where x and y represented the mol ratio between Ce and Ti9Zr1. The CexTiy catalysts were prepared by the method as described for Cex(Ti9Zr1)y. For physically closely contacted mixture catalysts, Cex(Ti9Zr1)y-PCCM and CexTiy-PCCM catalysts, given amounts of 1–10 µm powder CeO2 and 1–10 µm powder Ti9Zr1 or TiO2 were mixed completely and then closely contacted under 20 MPa to form tablets. The element compositions of Cex(Ti9Zr1)y-PCCM and CexTiy-PCCM catalysts were as the same as those of the corresponding Cex(Ti9Zr1)y and CexTiy prepared by sol-gel. The obtained tablets were pulverized into 40–60 mesh for direct use without any thermal treatment. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts were characterized by nitrogen adsorption and desorption isotherms, XRD, Raman, XPS, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, NH3-TPD and TPSR. The details of characterization were described in supplementary material. 2.3 Catalyst activity evaluation The performance of CeTiZr catalysts during the catalytic oxidation of CH2Cl2 was evaluated using a micro-reactor made of a quartz tube (inner diameter, 4 mm). In a standard test, 100 mg of grain catalyst (40–60 mesh) was packed in the reactor bed, over which the feed composed of 1000 ppm CH2Cl2/air flowed at 50 mL min−1 at 30,000 mL g−1 h−1. The reaction was carried out within 100–500 °C. The reactant and organic products in the effluent were determined with two on-line gas chromatographs equipped with flame ionization detectors (FID), one for the quantitative analysis of CH2Cl2 and the organic chlorinated products, and the other additionally equipped with a methanizer for CO and CO2. The conversion was calculated by subtracting the outlet CH2Cl2 concentration ([CH2Cl2]) from the inlet [CH2Cl2] and dividing by the inlet [CH2Cl2]. Cl2 content in the effluent was determined by a titration of 0.0125 M NaOH aqueous solution (through which effluent stream bubbles) with ferrous ammonium sulfate using N,N-diethyl-p-phenylenediamine as an indicator [27]. 2.4 In situ FT-IR Nicolet 6700 FTIR equipped with liquid nitrogen cooled mercury-cadmium- telluride detector was used to operate in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) experiments. DRIFTS cell (Harrick, HVC-DRP) fitted with CaF2 window was used as a reaction chamber that allowed the sample to be heated up to 500 °C, and the spectrum was recorded within 4000–1000 cm−1 at the resolution of 4 cm−1 and 64 scans. 80 mg of grain catalyst (40–60 mesh) was packed into DRIFTS cell. Before pyridine adsorption (Py-FT-IR), the sample was pretreated at 400 °C with 20% O2/Ar feed at 30 mL min−1 for 2 h. Then pyridine was introduced into the sample cell with a hypodermic syringe at 50 °C. The spectrum of pyridine adsorbed on the sample was recorded after the vacuum reached 10−3 mbar. For the spectrum of CH2Cl2 oxidation, the sample was pretreated at 400 °C by flowing 20% O2/Ar for 2 h with subsequent exposure to 1000 ppm CH2Cl2 balanced with 20% O2/Ar at various temperatures. Then the sample was purged with 20% O2/Ar for 30 min and the corresponding spectrum was recorded. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Physical structure The XRD patterns of Ce-Ti-Zr samples are shown in Fig. 1. For TiO2, there appear several peaks at 25.4, 37.8, 48.1, 54.0, 55.2 and 62.8 °, being the reflections from TiO2 anatase (JCPDS No. 21-1272). With Zr addition, the diffraction peaks of anatase become significantly weak, and the peak at 25.4° shifts to 25.2°, indicating that Zr species (Zr4+, 0.078 nm) enters into TiO2 (Ti4+, 0.061 nm) anatase, forming solid solution of Zr-O-Ti [28]. Correspondingly, the lattice parameter of anatase increases to some extent ( Table 1). Weak reflections from anatase of Ce1Ti9 and Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 are observed. Increasing Ce/Ce+Ti+Zr or Ce/Ce+Ti to 0.5, new diffraction peaks ascribed to CeO2 fluorite appear at 28.8, 33.3, 47.9 and 56.8 ° (JCPDS No. 34-0394). At the same time, the reflections from anatase disappear, really due to the increase in either Ce-O-Ti or TiO2 defects. The formation of weak longer bonds of Ce-O or Ti-O in cubic fluorite-like Ce-O-Ti solid solution structure was observed previously by EXAFS and further confirmed by the first-principles calculations [29]. Additionally, a strong interaction between CeO2 and TiO2 leads to the formation of highly defective TiO2. Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 and Ti9Zr1 present surface area of 88 and 85 m2 g−1, larger than TiO2 (22 m2 g−1), which is related to the decrease in the crystallite size of anatase from 21 nm for TiO2 to 9 and 12 nm, respectively, consistent with the result observed by TEM (Fig. S1A). Here, the growth of TiO2 crystallites is inhibited by the formation of Ce-O-Ti and Zr-O-Ti species. On the other hand, the addition of Ti or Zr into CeO2 fluorite decreases the size of CeO2 nano-particles to some extent, and the corresponding surface area is 85–100 m2 g−1, and the pore size, 3.9 ± 1.4 nm. The exposed planes of the catalysts with anatase and fluorite structures are observed by HRTEM to be < 101 > crystal plane of TiO2 anatase and < 111 > crystal plane of CeO2 fluorite, respectively (Fig. S1B). For Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 sample, the crystal planes related to TiO2 anatase is not observed, probably due to too small nano- particles with anatase structure resulted from Ce-O-Ti and Zr-O-Ti species. Raman spectra are shown in Fig. 2. For TiO2, there appear several bands at 142, 397, 516 and 640 cm−1, characteristic Eg, B1 g, A1 g+B1 g, and Eg modes of anatase, respectively [22]. For Ce1Ti9 and Ti9Zr1, the bands become weak greatly, but no bands ascribed to m-ZrO2 (at 181 cm−1) and t-ZrO2 (at 269 cm−1) [30] or CeO2 (at 463 cm−1) are observed. For Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9, the formation of Ce-O-Ti or Zr-O-Ti may influence the intensity of Eg vibration mode owing to the increase of oxygen vacancies [22]. As known, two oxygen ions sited at C4 axis of the oxygen octahedron are related to Eg vibration mode. Oxygen ion could be easily lost under reduction conditions [31]. The band at 463 cm−1 recognized as F2 g mode of fluorite phase [32] is dominant on CeO2 spectrum. For Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 and Ce5Ti5, the band at 463 cm−1 becomes asymmetrical, due to the increase in defects [15], probably through the formation of Ce-O-Ti and Ce-O-Zr species, which is supported by no appearance of TiO2 and ZrO2 bands. 3.2 Chemical states and reducibility Fig. 3 exhibits XPS spectra of O 1 s, Ti 2p, Zr 3d and Ce 3d in Ce-Ti-Zr samples. O 1 s peaks are deconvoluted into two peaks (Fig. 3A): one with binding energy (BE) of 529.8–530.2 eV is assigned to lattice oxygen (Olatt), and the other with BE of 531.2–531.4 eV, to surface-adsorbed oxygen (Osur), such as O2 2-, O2 - and O- [33]. For TiO2, BE of Olatt is found to be ca. 530.1 eV and increases with Zr addition, due to “Ti←O” through the formation of Zr-O-Ti. Ce5Ti5 and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 present lower BE of Olatt (529.9 eV) than Ce1Ti9 (530.0 eV) and Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 (530.1 eV), because of the formation of CeO2 fluorite with low BE of Olatt (529.8 eV). Moreover, the Osur/Ototal ratio is in the order of Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 > Ce5Ti5 > Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 > CeO2 ~ Ti9Zr1 > Ce1Ti9 > TiO2 ( Table 2). The increase in Osur may be a contribution from the increase in oxygen vacancy resulted from electron-transfer processes, and defective structure through the formation of Ti-O-Zr, Ce-O-Ti and Ce-O-Zr. Here, BE of Ti 2p3/2 decreases from 458.9 eV for Ti9Zr1 to 458.5 eV for Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 (Fig. 3B), and BE of Zr 3d5/2, from 182.5 eV for Ti9Zr1 to 182.2–182.4 eV (Fig. 3C). This phenomenon indicates that the oxidation state of Ti or Zr species exists between trivalent and tetravalent. The phase transformation of Zr species may cause BE shift. Here, the separated phase of Zr species cannot exist, due to the formation of Ce-O-Zr and Ti-O-Zr solid. Thus, the modification of Zr 3d5/2 should be ascribed to the effect of chemical environment on Zr's valence. For Ce 3d, six peaks at 882.5, 888.5, 898.3, 901.2, 907.7 and 916.6 eV are ascribed to Ce4+, while other four peaks at 880.9, 885.3, 900.0 and 904.0 eV (Fig. 3D) are from Ce3+ contribution [34]. It should be noted that the proportion of Ce3+ increases significantly with the decrease of Ce content (Table 2). For Ce1Ti9 and Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9, Ce3+ is likely to be surrounded by Ti or Zr, which can be conducive to forming oxygen vacancies on TiO2 anatase, while the promoted oxygen vacancies by Ti-O-Zr are favorable to the formation of Ce3+. The oxygen sub-lattice is significantly distorted, leading to destabilization of oxide ions in terms of long Ce-O and Ti-O and short Ce-O and Ti-O bonds [29]. Ce3+/Ce increases greatly to 0.43 and 0.49 for Ce1Ti9 and Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 from 0.15 for CeO2. However, for Ce5Ti5 and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5, the increase in Ce3+/Ce becomes small, due to small modification of Ce-O bonds in fluorite. H2-TPR profiles of Ce-Ti-Zr samples are shown in Fig. 4A. For CeO2, there appears a broad reduction peak in a range of 243–570 °C, ascribed mainly to the reduction of surface Ce4+ species. A shoulder peak on the left side of reduction peak results from the reduction of both Ce4+ species on small CeO2 nano-particles and surface oxygen [35]. With Ti and Zr addition, the reduction profiles delay to about 310 °C, indicating that small CeO2 nano-particles disappear, and the peaks can be assigned to reduction of surface oxygen and Ce4+ species, because the reduction of Ti or Zr species is difficult within the experimental temperature [22,30]. Moreover, the temperature on the right side of the reduction peak of Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 increases to 647 °C. H2 consumption (Table 2) for Ti9Zr1 is 0.05 mmol g−1, which should be used for the reduction of surface oxygen, much lower than that for Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 (0.26 mmol g−1). Considering O2-TPD result (Fig. 4B) that the amount of surface oxygen on Ti9Zr1 and Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 is similar (Table 2), H2 consumption for the reduction of Ce4+ in Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 can be estimated to be 0.21 mmol g−1. Based on XPS data, the total amount of Ce4+ in the bulk and surface of Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 is estimated to be 0.54 mmol g−1 (SI), and H2 consumption needed for reducing all Ce4+ is 0.27 mmol g−1, which is near the value for Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9, indicating that most of bulk Ce4+ in Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 is reduced. For Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5, H2 consumption (0.77 mmol g−1) is also higher than that for the reduction of Ce4+ on the surface of CeO2 (0.51 mmol g−1), but is smaller than the calculated values needed for reducing all Ce4+, 1.52 mmol g−1 (SI). Probably, the reducibility of Ce4+ would be promoted to a greater extent by the contact of more Ti-O. O2-TPD can be used for investigating the mobility of surface oxygen. Generally, the temperature of oxygen desorption is as following: physically adsorbed oxygen (O2) < reversibly and chemically adsorbed oxygen (O2 2-) < irreversibly and chemically adsorbed oxygen (O2 -) < surface oxygen (O-) < lattice oxygen (O2-) [36,37]. Total oxygen desorption within 100–700 °C is deconvoluted into four desorption peaks with the maxima at about 250, 350, 450 and 600 °C (Fig. 4B), corresponding to O2 2-, O2 -, O- and O2-. For the samples with anatase structure, the desorption temperature of different oxygen species cannot be modified by Ce-O-Ti or Ti-O-Zr, that is to say, the strength distribution of oxygen adsorption in oxygen vacancy of anatase would be constant. Especially, Ti9Zr1 and Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 present similar characteristic profiles. Of surface oxygen, O2 2- desorption dominates, indicating that dissociation of O2 2- into O- on TiO2 anatase is difficult. Zr addition increases surface oxygen on TiO2 by 513% through an increase in oxygen vacancy (Table 2), which is verified by EPR (Fig. S2). Oxygen desorption on CeO2 shifts to high temperature to some extent, where O- contribution is significant, due to high activity for O2 2- dissociation of CeO2. Compared with anatase samples, a significant decrease in oxygen desorption is ascribed to less O2 2-. UV–visible spectra at 200–350 °C for WOx/CeO2 catalysts pre-treated with He flow and O2 flow exhibited that a large amount of O2 2- existed on oxygen vacancies, while O2 2- became much less on pure CeO2 [38]. Ti and Zr co-incorporated into CeO2 (Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5) enrich on the surface (XPS data) as TiO2/CeO2 and ZrO2/CeO2, which promote the formation of O2 2-, as WOx/CeO2 did. As a result, the dissociation of O2 2- is inhibited by 68%. In another experiment, Ce1Ti9-PCCM, Ce5Ti5-PCCM, Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9-PCCM and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5-PCCM (physically closely contacted mixtures of CeO2 and TiO2 or Ti9Zr1 particles (1–10 µm), as described in Experimental section) are used for investigating the relation between surface oxygen and structure (Fig. 4C). Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9-PCCM presents a significant increased O- (44%), compared with the calculated value based on O- amount of Ti9Zr1 and CeO2 (Table 2 and Table S1), indicating that O- from CeO2 can transfer over the interface between two separated particles to the surface of Ti9Zr1. Probably, O- is formed more quickly on CeO2, due to high ability of oxygen activation. While for Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5-PCCM, the contact of CeO2 domain with more Ti-O- or Zr-O- leads to the increase in O2 2- (44%), which inhibits O- formation (20%). For Ce1Ti9-PCCM and Ce5Ti5-PCCM, three kinds of surface oxygen decrease to some extent, compared with their calculated values, indicating that the transfer of surface oxygen to TiO2 surface containing a small amount of oxygen vacancy becomes not highly effective. 3.3 Acidity NH3-TPD profiles of Ce-Ti-Zr samples are divided into two parts, the desorption of NH3 adsorbed on weak acid (100–250 °C) and strong acid (250–600 °C), as shown in Fig. 5A. The acid density is estimated based on NH3 desorption normalized by surface area (Table 1). TiO2 presents broad acidity with weak and strong acids of 2.1 and 7.9 μmol m−2, respectively. For Ti9Zr1, the density of weak and strong acids is 4.8 and 13.4 μmol m−2, respectively, which are resulted from the production of defective or unsaturated sites due to Zr's entrance into TiO2. The incorporation of Ce (Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9) can create more defects, which promotes the formation of acidic sites, while a part of surface Ce-O-Ti species can be formed on strong acid sites composed of Ti-O-Zr. As a result, the total acidity is further promoted through the formation of Ce-O-Ti and Ce-O-Zr, accompanying a slight decrease in strong acid. Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 with fluorite structure presents the decreased acidity, especially for strong acid (250–550 °C), because CeO2 itself does not show much acidity. Probably, some highly defective TiO2 nano-particles on CeO2 contribute to the acidity of Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5. On Py-FT-IR pattern (Fig. 5B), an obvious band appears at 1444 cm−1, which suggests that the acidity be composed mainly of Lewis acid provided by Ti4+, Zr4+ and Ce4+/Ce3+ [39]. In hydroxyl section, main negative band is observed at 3680 cm−1 on the samples containing-Ti, indicating the interaction between Ti-OH and pyridine. Ti9Zr1 and Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 show another weak negative shoulder band at 3714 cm−1, which is almost not observed for Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5, suggesting that Ti-O-Zr species decreases greatly. For CeO2, there appear much weaker negative bands at 3707, 3683 and 3652 cm−1. 3.4 The activity for CH2Cl2 oxidation The activity of Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts for CH2Cl2 oxidation is evaluated as a function of temperature ( Fig. 6). Considering that strong adsorption of Cl produced during CH2Cl2 decomposition on Ce- and Ti-based species leads to the deactivation of catalysts, stable conversion data at a given temperature are taken after 60 min reaction. As seen in Fig. 6A, TiO2 presents a considerable activity with 90% conversion at 439 °C (Fig. 6C, Table 3). Zr addition by Zr/Zr+Ti of 0.1 promotes the activity of TiO2 only at low temperature and the temperature needed for 10% conversion shifts to 280 °C from 313 °C, which is related to the increase in acidity and oxygen vacancy. Raising Zr content can cause the decrease in Ti-OH, which is not favorable for the activity (Fig. S3A). With the incorporation of Ce or Ce+Zr into TiO2, (Ce1Ti9 or Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9), the conversion curve shifts significantly to low temperature (Fig. 6A and B), and the temperature needed for 90% conversion (T90) decreases down to 373 and 341 °C, respectively (lower than T90 obtained over other Lewis catalysts [40,41], such as Pt/Al2O3 catalysts [42,43]), implying that the formation of Ce-O-Ti is favorable for CH2Cl2 oxidation. Increasing Ce/Ce+Ti+Zr or Ce/Ce+Ti ratio to 0.5, a slight decrease in conversion at each temperature is observed with the increase in T90 to 398 and 414 °C, respectively. Obviously, the promoted activity of Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts should be related to the synergism between Ce, Ti and Zr species. Considering that the initial activities of TiO2 and Ti9Zr1 are similar to those of Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 (Fig. S3B), while the initial activity of CeO2 is poor, it is reasonable to deduce that Ti species (Ti-OH) is the active sites of Ce-Ti-Zr and Ce-Ti catalysts. Therefore, the rate at 250 °C estimated based on the mol of transformed CH2Cl2 per square meter per second normalized by Ti % (XPS data) (Table S2) vs Ce/Ce+Ti+Zr can be used to investigate this synergism. The rates of Ti9Zr1, Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 are 0.65 × 10−3, 6.45 × 10−3 and 5.66 × 10−3 μmol s−1 m−2 ( Fig. 7A), respectively, while the ones of three corresponding catalysts without Zr are 0, 3.41 × 10−3 and 1.97 × 10−3 μmol s−1 m−2. Here, there exists a large difference in activity either between Ti9Zr1 and Ce-Ti-Zr or between TiO2 and Ce-Ti. Generally, strong Cl adsorption leads to the decrease in activity of Ti- or Ce-based catalysts during CVOC's oxidation, and Cl removal from the surface of these catalysts was a slow step [15]. Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9-PCCM and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5-PCCM show much higher rates (5.31 ×10−3 and 6.38 ×10−3 μmol s−1 m−2) (Fig. 7A and Fig. S4) than their calculated values (0.55 ×10−3 and 0.37 ×10−3 μmol s−1 m−2 (SI)), indicating that the Ti atom surrounded by Ce atom is highly active. DFT calculation showed that Cl species prefers to occupying oxygen vacancy during CVOC's oxidation [25]. According to the fact that a considerable amount of surface oxygen exists on Ti9Zr1, it can be deduced that the rate of producing surface oxygen on Ti9Zr1 during the reaction is not quick enough to meet the competition of surface oxygen with Cl species for oxygen vacancy. While surface oxygen effectively produced on CeO2 can transfer over their interface between the separated CeO2 and Ti9Zr1, and reach to oxygen vacancy of Ti9Zr1. The transfer of active oxygen species between particles could occur under the solid-solid soot-catalyst contact, which greatly promoted catalytic combustion of soot [44]. Although strong Cl adsorption occurs on CeO2 surface, oxygen molecules can still obtain electron from Ce3+ species to form surface oxygen species. The increase in activity of Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9-PCCM and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5-PCCM is related to the synergism between surface oxygen from CeO2 and Ti-OH from Ti9Zr1 species. It should be noted that the activities of Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9-PCCM and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5-PCCM are similar to those of Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5. This phenomenon can be ascribed to small difference in the accessibility of surface oxygen near Ti-OH. Compared with Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9-PCCM and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5-PCCM, Ce1Ti9-PCCM and Ce5Ti5-PCCM present low rates, 2.73 × 10−3 and 1.15 × 10−3 μmol s−1 m−2, respectively (Fig. 7A, Table S2), really due to less oxygen vacancy on TiO2 surface. That is to say, the increase in oxygen vacancy resulted from Zr addition is critical to oxygen transfer. On the other hand, the rates are approximately proportional to total surface oxygen density obtained by O2-TPD test (Fig. 7B). Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 and Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9-PCCM possess the promoted surface oxygen through the increase in oxygen vacancy, and thus show high apparent activity. The limited dynamic production of surface oxygen on Ti9Zr1 during the reaction due to Cl adsorption leads to its poor activity. Setting the temperature at 310 °C, the effect of oxygen concentration [O2] on CH2Cl2 oxidation was investigated ( Fig. 8). Within 0.1–20% [O2], the conversion over Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 increases more quickly with [O2] than that over Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5. While Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 presents higher rate than Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 (Fig. 8 inset). This difference in rate increases with the decrease in [O2], due to much higher oxygen storage of CeO2 fluorite structure than TiO2 ansaste with Ce-O-Ti and Ce-O-Zr species, and thus Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 can maintain high surface oxygen at low [O2]. The rate approaches each other at 20% [O2], where active surface oxygen is enough to oxidize intermediates adsorbed on Ti species. With general consideration, CH2Cl2 molecules are activated on Ti-OH species of Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts to form reactive intermediate, Ti-OCH2Cl or Ti-OCH2-O-Ti, through the abstraction of Cl atom as HCl [17]. Here, the chloride of HCl can strongly adsorb on Ti4+ Lewis acid to form Ti-Cl. With the increase in [O2], the attack of surface oxygen from CeO2 to Ti-Cl becomes effective. Without abundant surface oxygen, Cl removal becomes difficult, which results in low accessibility of Ti-OH sites for CH2Cl2 and low oxidation activity. Apparent activation energies (Ea) were calculated with 95% confidence limits using the dependence of conversion (below 20%) on the temperature (Table 3). For Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts, Ea value is in a range of 57–75 KJ mol−1, while CeO2 presents higher Ea, 97 KJ mol−1, which is similar to Ea obtained for Deacon over CeO2 [45], indicating that Cl removal from CeO2 occurs at high temperature through Deacon reaction during CH2Cl2 oxidation [35]. In the presence of Ti-OH, Cl removal as HCl is greatly promoted, while surface oxygen from CeO2 maintains dynamically the removal of Cl in oxygen vacancy near Ti-OH, and Zr addition increases oxygen vacancy of TiO2. As reported in the literature (Table S3), Co- and Cr-based catalysts were highly active for CVOC's oxidation, and their areal rates at 250 °C based on the mol of transformed CH2Cl2 per square meter per second for CH2Cl2 oxidation in the feed of 1000 ppm CH2Cl2 at GHSV of 30,000 mL g−1 h−1 were 0.24 × 10−3 and 0.43 × 10−3 μmol s−1 m−2, respectively. With the increase in GHSV or the decrease in CH2Cl2 concentration, Pt and Pd catalysts presented the promoted rates of 0.51 × 10−3 and 1.03 × 10−3 μmol s−1 m−2, respectively. Under the similar condition, the corresponding rate obtained over Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 is 1.74 × 10−3 μmol s−1 m−2. Therefore, high activity of Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts with Ti-O-Ce and Ti-O-Zr species for CH2Cl2 oxidation can be ascribed to a synergism between effective adsorption and activation of oxygen on Ce species, Cl removal and high accessibility of Ti-OH promoted by surface oxygen, and abundant Lewis acidity. 3.5 Distribution of products The distribution of products in the effluent was determined by TPSR analyses (Fig. S5). Main products are composed of CO/CO2, CH3Cl, HCl and Cl2. Cl2 cannot be detected until 300 °C, where Deacon reaction (HCl + O2 → Cl2 + H2O) starts. The selectivity for Cl2 increases with temperature. As reported, either CeO2 fluorite or TiO2 rutile was considered to be active catalysts for Deacon reaction [45,46]. The selectivity for Cl2 at 350 °C over CeO2, Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5, Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9, Ti9Zr1 and TiO2 is 41%, 25%, 16%, 10% and 13%, respectively ( Fig. 9A). HCl as another inorganic Cl species is produced within reaction temperature. Especially, for Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 with high activity, HCl is main inorganic Cl species before 300 °C. Because HCl in the effluent adsorbs strongly on the interface of pipes and joggles made of different materials, HCl in the effluent cannot be determined correctly, and thus the estimation of Cl balance is difficult. No chlorination products, such as CHCl3 or CCl4, are detected within FID limitation (1 ppm). CH3Cl is produced mainly at 200–450 °C with the order of best selectivity as CeO2 (0%) < Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 (8%) < Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 (14%) < TiO2 (23%) < Ti9Zr1 (38%) (Fig. 9B). Here, CH3Cl is formed by two pathways, chlorination of intermediate methoxy into which formaldehyde is transformed from -O-CH2-O- through Cannizzaro mechanism in the presence of basic catalyst [47] and the transfer of hydride from intermediate -O-CH2-O- to -O-CH2-Cl [17]. No CH3Cl is detected on CeO2, indicating that the formation of -O-CH2-O- on Ti-OH species is responsible for CH3Cl. An increase in surface oxygen with Ce content is favorable for the oxidation of -O-CH2-O-. With the increase in [CH2Cl2] from 500 to 2000 ppm or the decrease in [O2] from 20% to 5%, CH3Cl selectivity over Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 increases gradually (Fig. S6A and S6B), due to surface oxygen being not enough to meet the oxidization of all -O-CH2-O-. For Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9-PCCM, the best selectivity for CH3Cl increases to 35% from 14% obtained on Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 (Fig. S7). The transfer of surface oxygen for a large amount of Ti-OH is not enough. While for Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5-PCCM, Ce1Ti9-PCCM and Ce5Ti5-PCCM, the decrease in CH3Cl is related to the increase in surface oxygen per Ti-OH. This result indicates the oxidation involves in surface oxygen. When the conversion approaches 90%, the selectivity for CO/CO2 over the Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts reaches 99% or higher. The order of CO2 selectivity is followed by CeO2 > Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 > Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 > Ti9Zr1~TiO2 (Fig. 9B). Over CeO2 and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 with fluorite structure, CO2 selectivity increases from 38% and 20% at 250 °C to 48% and 32% at 350 °C, respectively. Within similar temperature range, Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 presents the increase in CO2 selectivity from 7% to 10%. Over TiO2 and Ti9Zr1, the final oxidation products mainly are CO, really due to their low activity for oxidation. And carbon balance reaches 98% or higher. 3.6 Catalyst stability and characterization of the used catalyst The stability of Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts was evaluated at 310 °C under the reaction condition as ascribed in Fig. 10. CeO2 presents low stable conversion of 10% within 50 h. TiO2 and Ti9Zr1 deactivate quickly within initial 60 min with the decrease in conversion from 55% and 86% to 20% and 35%, respectively. After 60 min, the deactivation becomes slow. At the same time, the selectivity for CH3Cl decreases with time, suggesting that Ti-OH related to the formation of O-CH2-O decrease (Fig. S8). The deactivation caused by coke deposition will occur often in the catalytic combustion of CVOCs. Ti-based catalysts without Brønsted acid were susceptible to the adsorption of chlorine formed during CVOC's decomposition [18,22]. TiO2's Cl poisoning is related to the formation of Ti-Cl, which results in the decrease in Ti-OH and Ti4+ Lewis acid sites [48] needed for CH2Cl2 activation. In the another experiment, turning off CH2Cl2 in feed, the activity of TiO2 and Ti9Zr1 can be restored at 310 °C. Here, the substitution of surface oxygen for Cl is easy, probably due to higher bond energy of Ti-O. Obviously, the production of surface oxygen on TiO2 and Ti9Zr1 during the reaction is not quick enough to meet this substitution. With Ce incorporation, the conversion over Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 maintains at 77% and 50% for at least 50 h. Quick production and transfer of surface oxygen produced on Ce species promote Cl removal through the substitution for Cl atom on oxygen vacancy. Moreover, Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9-PCCM and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5-PCCM composed of separated CeO2 and Ti9Zr1 particles present stable 78% and 56% conversion within the same duration, although only 10% and 20% stable conversion is obtained over CeO2 and Ti9Zr1. This result verifies that the surface oxygen transferring over the interface between CeO2 and Ti9Zr1 at 20% [O2] can substitute Cl on oxygen vacancy, which is responsible for high stable activity of Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts during CVOC's oxidation. It should be noted that the stable activity of Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5-PCCM is higher than that for Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5. This result is related to a synergism between more surface oxygen from CeO2 domain and more strong acid sites from Ti9Zr1. The distributions of CO, CO2, CH3Cl and Cl2 over Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 with high stability (Fig. S8) is similar to those observed in Fig. 9. XPS determination for the used Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts exhibits no obvious modification in chemical states of Ce, Ti and Zr (Fig. S9). However, Cl deposition on Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts was observed (Table S4) as the following order, Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 (4.2%) > Ti9Zr1 (3.2%) > Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 (2.2%) > TiO2 (1.9%). Here, oxygen vacancy in fluorite and anatase without Ce-O-Ti species is favorable for Cl deposition. H2-TPR tests (Fig. S10) exhibit that the reduction of Ce4+ ions shifts to high temperature, relative to that for the fresh Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts, due to Cl presence. H2 consumption becomes small slightly (Table 2), which is ascribed to the decrease in surface oxygen, due to Cl deposition in oxygen vacancy. However, Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts maintains high stable activity within at least 50 h, indicating that Cl deposition occurs on the sites far from Ce-O-Ti active species. 3.7 The effect of water Adding 7000 ppm (V/V) water into the feed, the conversion curve over Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 is similar to that in dry feed ( Fig. 11A). CH3Cl as the product formed by the attack of hydride ion to -O-CH2Cl decreases significantly (Fig. 11B), indicating that -O-CH2Cl is quickly converted into -O-CH2-O- through the second abstraction of HCl. Inorganic Cl species is only HCl. CO2 selectivity over Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9, TiO2 and Ti9Zr1 increases to some extent (Fig. 11C), probably due to the decrease in Cl deposition. This result is quite different from the case of Al2O3 and Pt/Al2O3, where CH2Cl2 is converted in wet feed to CO, CH3Cl and HCl with 1/1/3 mol ratio [17]. Herman et al. found that H2O cannot adsorb on anatase TiO2 (101) at 300 K or higher [49]. Lykhach et al. found the existing of hydroxyl groups on CeO2 at 700 K in SRPES spectra [50]. Generally, the effect of water can be ascribed to its competitive adsorption with reactant molecules on active sites and promotion of Cl removal [35]. The Ce-OH produced through water dissociation is not favorable for the formation of surface active oxygen [51]. Here, most of CH2Cl2 is oxidized into CO and CO2, indicating that the formation of Ce-OH on Ce-O-Ti species is inhibited to a large extent. For TiO2 and Ti9Zr1, the conversion curve section at 150–300 °C shifts to high temperature in the presence of water, where the adsorption and activation of oxygen molecules is inhibited to some extent, due to -OH's (resulted from water dissociation) occupying oxygen vacancy. Raising temperature, water adsorption becomes weak, and thus the accessibility of surface oxygen increases. At the same time, the increased -OH still can promote significantly Cl removal, and the conversion increases with temperature quickly. Without Cl adsorption, Ti-OH is accessible for CH2Cl2 and surface oxygen is available on oxygen vacancy. As a result, the activity of Ti9Zr1 is near to its initial activity in dry feed. Similar phenomenon is also observed on TiO2. The fact that high conversion curve sections over Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 and Ti9Zr1 almost overlap verifies that the formation of active intermediate (-O-CH2-O-) on Ti-OH is a common slow step. 3.8 In situ FT-IR spectra of CH2Cl2 oxidation 3.8.1 Ti9Zr1 and Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 In situ FT-IR spectra were recorded over Ti9Zr1 and Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 at 50–400 °C after treated in 20% O2/Ar and then in the feed containing 1000 ppm CH2Cl2 in 20% O2/Ar. For Ti9Zr1 ( Fig. 12A), there appear several bands at 2960–2834 cm−1, assigned to C-H stretching vibrations. In hydroxyl group section, the negative bands with the centers at 3714–3671 cm−1 are assigned usually to strong surface hydroxyl groups, Ti-OH, indicating that the adsorption of CH2Cl2 occurs through the interaction between Ti-OH and CH2Cl2. Generally, Cl atom from CH2Cl2 combines hydroxyl group of oxides, such as Al-OH [17] or Fe-OH [52] to produce HCl and -O-CH2Cl. At 200 °C or higher, the bands observed at 2834, 1565, 1378 and 1365 cm−1 can be ascribed to C-H stretching, COO- asymmetric stretching, C-H deformation and COO- symmetric stretching vibrations of formate ions, respectively [47]. Other bands within 1554–1590 cm−1 are related to formate on Zr or to acetate ions on Ti or Zr. At 250–400 °C, all the mentioned bands grow in intensity, indicating that formate ions are formed through the interaction between CH2Cl2 and hydroxyl group. For Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9, the negative hydroxyl bands become much weaker, although the frequencies of hydroxyl bands are not changed (Fig. 12B). Besides the bands at 2836, 1559, 1382 and 1363 cm−1 which are ascribed to stable formate ions, no other carboxylate species is observed. This result indicates that Ce addition promotes the supplement of surface oxygen so that the hydroxyl group is accessible for CH2Cl2 molecule to form active intermediate, -O-CH2-O- (1488 cm−1), even at high temperature, which is then converted quickly only to formate ions on Ti species. On the other hand, there appears a strong broad band with a center at 3518 cm−1, which can be ascribed to binding hydroxyl group of water produced during HCl + O2 → Cl2 + H2O. It should be noted that the band at 3518 cm−1 can be observed at 250 °C, which seems lower than the temperature (300 °C) at which Deacon occurs (Fig. 9A). The difference in temperature can be ascribed to the determination error of Cl2 content in the effluent, due to small difference in color for very low Cl2 content at 250 °C. Without oxygen, the intensity of negative hydroxyl bands over Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 increases significantly (Fig. S11), and all other bands maintain, indicating that the formation of containing-oxygen intermediate, -O-CH2-O- and formate ion, involves in Ti-OH and surface oxygen. 3.8.2 CeO2 and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 On the spectra of CH2Cl2 oxidation over CeO2 ( Fig. 13A), there appear similar negative bands in a range of 3732–3622 cm−1. The bands ascribed to formate ions at 2853, 1531, 1367 and 1359 cm−1 are observed at 200–300 °C. Generally, the pathway over CeO2 without Ti-OH can be considered that Cl atom of C-Cl adsorbs on Lewis acid and base oxygen combines carbocation to form Ce-OCH2Cl, which is further oxidized into carboxylates. The appearance of bands to acetate ions (1540, 1423 and 1378 cm−1 [53]) and maleate (1500, 1436 and 1341 cm−1 [54]) indicates that C-C coupling occurs, probably through the condensation of aldehyde (-CO, 1630 cm−1) by Cannizzaro mechanism. Raising temperature to 350 °C or higher, new bands at 1588, 1475 and 1445 cm−1 are observed, which are assigned to the CC degenerated stretching vibrations of aromatics ring [55]. At the same time, two strong bands appear at 1256 and 1215 cm−1 corresponding to phenolates, which are formed through the abstraction of Cl atom from chlorinated aromatics by basic O2- [54]. This O2- species can exist on the surface of CeO2 as moderate strong base. As known, the aromatization of methane or chlorinated methane could occur in the absence of oxygen [56]. Here, a significant aromatization of CH2Cl2 in the presence of oxygen is related to the deficiency of surface active oxygen on CeO2 during the reaction. Probably, the substitution of oxygen for adsorbed Cl atom is slow, which also leads to slow decomposition and oxidation of formate, acetate and maleate. Ti addition promotes Cl removal as HCl. On the other hand, a significant increase in Ti-OH is favorable for the formation of -O-CH2-O-, which can be directly oxidized into formate. Indeed, only bands at 2833, 1553, 1379 and 1364 cm−1 ascribed to formate ions are observed on the spectra of Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 (Fig. 13B). At 350 °C or higher, a broad shoulder band at 1577–1600 cm−1 is related to CC of aromatics produced on CeO2 domain far from Ti-OH. Correspondingly, the negative bands in a range of hydroxyl group at 3740–3650 cm−1 should be related to the substitution of Cl for hydroxyl group of CeO2 domain. A considerable amount of Ti-OH exists on the surface of Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 and Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5, as indicated by Py-FT-IR results. Reactive -O-CH2-O- species is formed on Ti-OH and converted only into formate ion, which can be oxidized into CO/CO2 in the presence or absence of gas oxygen, indicating that the oxidation of formate ions involves in surface oxygen. The roles of surface oxygen species on the catalytic oxidation of organic compounds have been explored extensively [57,58]. Electrophilic oxygen species with different stabilities and chemical reactivity are associated with adsorbed O2 in molecule and partially reduced oxygen species, such as O2 -, O2 2- and O-. The catalysts with either TiO2 anatase or CeO2 fluorite structure maintain high oxygen mobility due to abundance of oxygen vacancy, which may contribute to the reaction. This supports the idea about the following reaction pathway. CH2Cl2 interacts with Ti-OH site present in the Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts to form -O-CH2-O- intermediate through twice abstraction of chlorine atoms. -O-CH2-O- rearranges into formate species. Finally, formate species is oxidized into gas-phase reaction products (i.e., CO, CO2, and H2O). 4 Conclusion Ce-Ti-Zr mixed oxide catalysts with Ce/Ce+Ti+Zr ratio of 0.1–0.5 were prepared by sol-gel method and characterized by XRD, N2 isothermal adsorption and desorption, Raman, TEM, XPS, H2-TPR, O2-TPD, NH3-TPD and Py-FT-IR. TiO2 and Ti9Zr1 present anatase structure. For Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9, Zr4+ and Ce4+ can enter into the lattice of TiO2 to form Ti-O-Zr and Ti-O-Ce species. Zr increases the amount of Lewis acid by 82% and oxygen vacancy by 513%. Ce promotes the activation of oxygen molecules and mobility of surface oxygen during the reaction. Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 exists in a form of fluorite structure, in which Lewis acidity is increased through the enrichment of Ti and Zr species. High intensity of bands ascribed to hydroxyl group was observed on Py-FT-IR spectra of Ce-Ti-Zr samples. In CH2Cl2 oxidation, Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts show high activity, stability and selectivity for CO, CO2 and HCl. The substitution of surface oxygen for Cl can promote Cl removal and maintain the accessibility of hydroxyl group, which leads to the decrease in Ea. The apparent rate based on the mol of transformed CH2Cl2 per square meter per second normalized by Ti content is 5.66 × 10−3–6.45 × 10−3 μmol s−1 m−2 at 250 °C at 30,000 mL g−1 h−1. The stability tests at 310 °C show that TiO2 and Ti9Zr1 deactivate quickly within 60 min, while the catalysts containing Ce-O-Ti maintain high activity for at least 50 h. The investigation of physically closely contacted mixture of separated CeO2 and TiO2 or Ti9Zr1 particles verifies that surface oxygen can transfer over their interface and promote greatly the stable activity of catalysts. A synergism between Ti-OH and surface oxygen is responsible for high activity and stability for CH2Cl2 oxidation. No chlorination products such as CHCl3 and CCl4 is detected within FID limitation (1 ppm). CH3Cl is produced at 200–450 °C with the order of best selectivity as CeO2 < Ce5(Ti9Zr1)5 < Ce1(Ti9Zr1)9 < TiO2 < Ti9Zr1 through the transfer of hydride from intermediate -O-CH2-O- to -O-CH2-Cl. Below 300 °C, inorganic Cl species exists as HCl. In situ FT-IR on Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts shows that CH2Cl2 interacts with Ti-OH to form reactive -O-CH2-O-, which quickly rearranges only into formate ions. Finally, the products containing oxygen are oxidized with surface oxygen into CO and CO2. coredata.dc:description: Ce-Ti-Zr mixed oxide catalysts prepared by sol-gel method were used in catalytic combustion of CH2Cl2. The characterization reveals that the incorporation of Ce and Zr into TiO2 anatase or Ti and Zr into CeO2 fluorite promotes hydroxyl groups, Lewis acidity and surface oxygen through the formation of Ti-O-Zr, Ti-O-Ce and Ce-O-Zr species. Ce-Ti-Zr catalysts show high activity for CH2Cl2 oxidation with the rate of 5.66 × 10−3–6.45 × 10−3 μmol s−1 m−2 at 250 °C and high stability for 50 h. The substitution of surface oxygen for Cl maintains the availability of Ti-OH and thus promotes Cl removal as HCl, which is verified by a great increase in the stable activity of physically closely contacted mixture of separated CeO2 and TiO2 or Ti9Zr1 particles. In situ FT-IR shows that CH2Cl2 interacts with Ti-OH to form -O-CH2-O-, which is quickly rearranged into formate. Finally, formate is oxidized with surface oxygen into CO or CO2.
coredata.dc:title: CH2Cl2 catalytic oxidation over Ce-Ti-Zr mixed oxide catalysts
